articles.headline: The News About the News Business Is Getting Grimmer
articles.snippet: Mass layoffs, closures and reader fatigue are afflicting news organizations as Americans prepare for a consequential election year.
articles.abstract: Mass layoffs, closures and reader fatigue are afflicting news organizations as Americans prepare for a consequential election year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even by the standards of a news business whose fortunes have plummeted in the digital age, the last few weeks have been especially grim for American journalism.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, John Koblin, Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: New Hampshire and Iowa Reveal Broader Weaknesses for Trump
articles.snippet: As Donald J. Trump pivots to a general election, early results point at the rough road ahead with critical independent voters.
articles.abstract: As Donald J. Trump pivots to a general election, early results point at the rough road ahead with critical independent voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks, Donald J. Trump has romped through Iowa and New Hampshire without breaking a sweat, muscling out rivals for the Republican nomination and soaking up adoration from crowds convinced he will be the next president of the United States.
articles.byline: By Michael C. Bender and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Shipping Costs Soar in Wake of Red Sea Attacks
articles.snippet: Ships risking Houthi attacks must pay high insurance premiums, while vessels avoiding the region lose time going around Africa.
articles.abstract: Ships risking Houthi attacks must pay high insurance premiums, while vessels avoiding the region lose time going around Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: For about two months, a barrage of missile and drone attacks in the Red Sea by Houthi militants has posed a difficult choice to shipowners using the Suez Canal: risk an airborne strike and pay sharply higher insurance rates, or forgo the canal and take the longer route around Africa, snarling schedules and entailing higher fuel charges.

articles.headline: After Early Primary Victories, Republicans in Congress Fall in Line Behind Trump
articles.snippet: The former president’s win in New Hampshire has melted away much of the remaining opposition to him among Republicans on Capitol Hill.
articles.abstract: The former president’s win in New Hampshire has melted away much of the remaining opposition to him among Republicans on Capitol Hill.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, the Georgia Republican and die-hard ally of former President Donald J. Trump, was exasperated with her colleagues as she left the House floor last Thursday evening.

articles.headline: Boeing Reinstalled Panel That Later Blew Out of 737 Max Jet
articles.snippet: Employees at its Washington State factory are said to have removed the door plug for further work before the plane was delivered to Alaska Airlines.
articles.abstract: Employees at its Washington State factory are said to have removed the door plug for further work before the plane was delivered to Alaska Airlines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly three weeks after a hole blew open on a Boeing 737 Max 9 during an Alaska Airlines flight, terrifying passengers, new details about the jet’s production are intensifying scrutiny of Boeing’s quality-control practices.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Mark Walker

articles.headline: From Opposite Sides of War, a Hunt for Elusive Facts
articles.snippet: The Israel-Hamas conflict has produced a prodigious amount of disinformation, putting people who fact-check claims — especially those who live in the region — back on their heels.
articles.abstract: The Israel-Hamas conflict has produced a prodigious amount of disinformation, putting people who fact-check claims — especially those who live in the region — back on their heels.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the frantic early hours of Oct. 7, amid wailing sirens and word of gunfights along Israel’s southern border, Achiya Schatz rushed with his toddler and heavily pregnant wife into a bomb shelter near Tel Aviv.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Grew at 3.3% Rate in Latest Quarter
articles.snippet: The increase in gross domestic product, while slower than in the previous period, showed the resilience of the recovery from the pandemic’s upheaval.
articles.abstract: The increase in gross domestic product, while slower than in the previous period, showed the resilience of the recovery from the pandemic’s upheaval.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy continued to grow at a healthy pace at the end of 2023, capping a year in which unemployment remained low, inflation cooled and a widely predicted recession never materialized.

articles.headline: The One Part of the Housing Market That’s Growing
articles.snippet: As owners remain reluctant to put their properties on the market, developers are rushing to build new homes to meet demand.
articles.abstract: As owners remain reluctant to put their properties on the market, developers are rushing to build new homes to meet demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Joel Adler decided it was time to downsize from his six-bedroom house in Parkland, Fla., where he had lived for more than 20 years, he was disappointed with the lack of options.
